channel.title: BUbreakingSectionTwo
channel.description: This is a randomly ordered feed of the most recent entries from BUbreakingSectionTwo, skipping any feeds with errors.

item.title: U.S. Military’s Boat Strikes Planning Takes On New Significance
item.description: The details could raise questions about who was responsible for a follow-up strike on Sept. 2 — the commander who ordered it or the defense secretary.

item.title: You don’t need to have fun at work—take it from NBA head coach Joe Mazzulla: ‘Fun is a cop-out sometimes when things aren’t going well’
item.description: The famously intense Mazzulla was fielding a question about "fun" from a child reporter: "I struggle with that, to be honest with you."

item.title: Two months into the new fiscal year and the U.S. government is already spending more than $10 billion a week servicing national debt
item.description: Tariffs will bring in $300 billion to $400 billion a year, which would help to pay a fraction of the interest payments of more than $1 trillion in 202...

item.title: Palantir CEO Alex Karp defends being an ‘arrogant prick’—and says more CEOs should be, too
item.description: Karp argues extreme confidence—checked by a “painfully flat” internal culture—is the only way to resist the "bailout culture" of modern corporate Amer...

item.title: The Childhood Vaccine Under Threat, and Trump’s Newest Push for Gas-Powered Cars
item.description: Plus, the race to save music history.

item.title: CEOs are making the business case for AI—and dispelling talk of a bubble
item.description: Also: All the news and watercooler chat from Fortune.

item.title: Immigrants’ Fears
item.description: We explain how Afghan refugees in America are experiencing the fallout from a D.C. shooting.

item.title: New York Times Sues Pentagon Over First Amendment Rights
item.description: The lawsuit said the Defense Department’s new set of rules for journalists “violates the Constitution’s guarantees of due process, freedom of speech a...

item.title: Trump to Host Congo and Rwanda Leaders for Peace Talks in Persistent Conflict
item.description: The president will meet with the leaders of Rwanda and the Democratic Republic of Congo to advance a deal meant to end a long war in eastern Congo.

item.title: How Anthropic grew—and what the $183 billion giant faces next
item.description: In our latest Fortune cover story, AI editor Jeremy Kahn explores what's driving Anthropic's growth.

item.title: Trump to Host Congo and Rwanda Leaders for Peace Talks in Persistent Conflict
item.description: The president will meet with the leaders of Rwanda and the Democratic Republic of Congo to advance a deal meant to end a long war in eastern Congo.

item.title: Spain Sees Itself as a Beacon for Immigrants. So Do Many Latin Americans.
item.description: The government presents its migrant policy as a welcoming alternative to U.S. crackdowns. But activists say those arriving on boats from Africa are ex...

item.title: Ruined Rice Fields and Broken Rail Lines: Sri Lanka Counts Cost of Cyclone
item.description: Officials estimate the damage runs into billions of dollars, a headache for the island nation just recovering from an economic crash.

item.title: How Israel’s Settlement Surge in the West Bank Is Displacing Palestinians
item.description: The Israeli government authorized 22 settlements in May, the largest expansion in decades, and Palestinian families are now being forced from their ho...

item.title: Snail Theft Hits France Before Holiday Rush
item.description: Shop owners say the thieves who took 990 pounds of snails must have been escargot cognoscenti.
